description:
Rickettsia fournieri is a species of Gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacteria belonging to the genus Rickettsia. It is a member of the spotted fever group of Rickettsia, which are known to cause various tick-borne diseases in humans.

R. fournieri was first isolated from a tick species, Rhipicephalus sanguineus, collected in France. It is named after the French microbiologist Georges Fournier, who contributed significantly to the study of Rickettsia infections.

The bacterium is small, coccobacillary in shape, and lacks a cell wall. It is an obligate intracellular parasite, meaning it can only replicate and survive within the living cells of its host, such as the cells of the tick vector or the human host.

R. fournieri is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected ticks, and it can cause a spotted fever-like illness. The clinical symptoms associated with R. fournieri infection are similar to other spotted fever group Rickettsia infections, including fever, headache, rash, and potentially more severe complications if left untreated.

Accurate identification and diagnosis of R. fournieri infection are crucial, as it can be treated with appropriate antibiotic therapy. Further research is ongoing to better understand the epidemiology, pathogenesis, and clinical manifestations of this Rickettsia species.
